Award.AwardTitle: IUSE: Collaborative Project: Engaged Student Learning: Design and Development, Level I: Broadening the Path to the STEM Profession Through Cybersecurity Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance and importance of this project resides in the diversification and broadening of the STEM talent pipeline in cybersecurity in predominantly undergraduate and liberal arts schools (small institutions). This is achieved by the creation of a curriculum that accommodates students of different levels of computer literacy, that focuses on experiential learning, and that utilizes institutional collaboration via cloud computing. This project will mitigate the challenges small institutions currently face in the cybersecurity area, for example, a tight computer science curriculum and the inability to support the expensive infrastructure required for cybersecurity education. Integrated into this project is research as to whether using this new curriculum and the related online projects, students will attain the same, or an increase, level of cybersecurity learning.

This project will address the above challenges by creating a range of cybersecurity learning opportunities that emphasize hands-on and realistic experimentation for students in small institutions. First, this project will attract a diverse population of students by introducing cybersecurity topics through multiple paths of study and engagement. Students will be introduced to cybersecurity concepts through manageable, stand alone course modules and laboratory exercises. Interested students can study further by taking two cybersecurity focused courses and cybersecurity capstone projects created by this project. Using all these materials students can create a cybersecurity concentration. Second, the project will use the Global Environment for Network Innovation (GENI) infrastructure in the development of empirical labs and the capstone project assignments. GENI offers an affordable cloud solution to small institutions that lack the infrastructure to support sophisticated computer labs. The learning impact of the new curriculum will be evaluated by quantitative competency assessments that are administered yearly. Student cybersecurity persistence will be assessed by a longitudinal study of the number of cybersecurity courses taken during a student's course of study. Qualitative assessment of the curriculum will take the form of student interviews and focus groups to gauge attitude towards course modules, perception of learning gains and comfort level with the pedagogies employed. In addition to the collaboration of three college level institutions, this project will leverage relationships with local community colleges to further develop a cybersecurity workforce. This partnership provides a diverse set of students that will support the evidence-based evaluation of student cybersecurity learning via this approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A difficult problem that Primarily Undergraduate (PUI) and Liberal Arts (LIA) institutions face when they teach Cybersecurity experientially is that they need to build and maintain expensive, sanitized cyber labs. Cloud-based learning module code and materials have shown the potential of reducing reliance on expensive physical infrastructure for Cybersecurity teaching, by devising comprehensive virtual labs especially on the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) cloud in this project.

This collaborative project has several goals in place to improve the cybersecurity education:

  • It aims to advance the diversity and participation of cybersecurity, and STEM in large, professionals by attracting a diverse, multidisciplinary population of LIA students through multiple paths of Cybersecurity study. Toward this, students have opportunities to be exposed to and study cybersecurity materials in standalone general education and computing modules.
  • It facilitates learning cybersecurity experientially with real-world experimentation in PUI and LIA institutions that cannot afford expensive, sanitized labs, by using cloud-based virtual computing environments including the GENI infrastructure. To this end, it develops up to date labs, comprehensive instructor manuals, and other material such as installation scripts, to facilitate the use of GENI labs and experiments for PUI and LIA instructors.
  • It disseminates the project materials including general education learning modules, experiential lab modules, learning path designs and assessment results to peer LIA institutions. It makes all the material of the modules and labs available on public websites. It plans to organize two workshops for instructors.

This project developed a set of educational materials including computer labs and general education modules. The Johns Hopkins University (JHU) team completed a set of GENI and VM- based labs on blockchain and digital certificates. These materials are publicly available to students and faculty through the project website (http://blogs.cofc.edu/cyberpaths/workshops/) and GENI website (http://www.cs.unc.edu/Research/geni/geniExercises/).

These materials were used in the classroom and student research projects for continuous feedback and improvement. With the assistance of the JHU team the College of Charleston team used GENI lab and general education modules in several courses to measure their effectiveness in improving cybersecurity literacy among students and attract students into the STEM field. The JHU team introduced the intrusion detection, blockchain and digital certificate modules in two courses of Introduction to Information Security and Computer Intrusion Detection in five semesters at JHU. Their usage has been instrumental to promoting teaching and educational experiences of involved faculty and students.

The JHU team engaged in regular exchanges with other researchers and practitioners in conferences and meetings about cybersecurity security research and education, including conference publications and presentations. The JHU team supported undergraduate and graduate students in research and development of cybersecurity experiments and labs. The JHU team helped out the two workshops hosted by the College of Charleston team in 2017 and 2018 that had participants from community colleges, colleges and high schools. Lastly, The JHU team disseminated project results through social media and crowdsourcing platforms, including JHU websites, Github and HackMD.
